transcripts.text: So there are somewhat different views, depending on whether you're a Republican or Democrat, on Bill Barr and whether he's worth the assault or even worth staying in the job in this investigation.  Ken Starr joins me right now, of course, the former Whitewater Independent Counsel, author of Contempt, a memoir of the Clinton investigation.  Ken, good to see you.
Good to see you, Neil.

Do you think any of this hostility the Democrats have expressed about the Attorney General is more based on what he might find and come up with down the road about the genesis of this whole investigation?

It's hard to explain it otherwise.  Why don't we want to know the truth?  How did all this come about?  A number of concerns have been raised.  Don't you really want to know the truth?  But instead, and I think it's really sad for the law, it's sad for the country, but welcome to politics, that they just viciously attack an honorable man.  They attack everything that he's doing.  By my lights, from my perspective, he's going by the book.  He's following the law.  He followed the regulations in terms of that famous and now infamous infamous March 24th letter, that did exactly what he was supposed to do.  And not even Bob Mueller, whining as he did in retrospect about it, was willing to say, you know, Bill, with all due respect, that was inaccurate.  It wasn't inaccurate.  And yet, Bill Barr is unfairly being savage.
Well, you read the report, obviously.  Yes, yes.  And the bullet points that the Attorney General provided mirror pretty much the findings of that report.

I think it stated the bottom line conclusions.  That's all the letter of March 24th from Bill Barr to the Congress purported to do.  What more could he do?  Now, they said, well, you should have released the summaries.  And he said, no, that's a judgment call.  I'm paraphrasing.

He was damned if he did or damned if he didn't.  They had to rush it out.  Why are you waiting?  Rush it out.  And then, you know, I guess the Mueller folks were saying you needed to provide more context and all that.  But time was of the essence because it was creating a firestorm, right?

And the adverb fully was used in the Bob Mueller letter of March 27th.  You didn't fully convey the context and say, oh, please, it's a 446-page report.  That's mission impossible.  I think it's unreasonable.
I'm calling on a snitty letter.

Well, and I think it was an unreasonable letter.  I'm very, very disappointed in someone who I have great respect for, and that's Bob Mueller.  He should not have written that letter.  And then Bill Barr did exactly the right thing by calling him up and saying, what's the problem?  Where's the beef?  And to say then that it wasn't accurate just suggests to me that Bob Mueller did a great disservice to the Justice Department and to Bill Barr.  Those are strong words.  I usually am a little bit more restrained, but I'm very upset about Bob Mueller's sort of opening the doors to the Democrats' vicious attacks on a very honorable attorney general.

You know, I'm curious, too, the chicken attack line on Bahar just the day before.  He was like a human piñata with Democrats and absorbing six hours of these body blows.  So he's a chicken.  He has a funny way of showing it.  Wasn't he more against being questioned by a separate attorney, a counsel that had nothing to do with members of that committee, most of whom are lawyers anyway?

Right.  He said, look, I'm not going to be questioned by staff.  I'm the attorney general of the United States.  It sounds a little braggadocious.  He was just being very straightforward.  I'm a cabinet officer and you have been elected members of the House.  So you do the questioning as opposed to bring in some.
And that was a Nadler last minute call.  Right.  So he knew the reaction he'd get.  It almost seemed like a set up.

It may have been a setup or it may have been a recognition.  They are dealing with an extraordinary able Attorney General of the United States who first and foremost is a superb lawyer.  Couple that with vast experience and he's going to be able to handle ably any questions including from staff.  But I think essentially what we have is a declaration of war by Jerry Nadler now joined by the Senate Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee.  Now the presidential candidates joining in the declaration of war.  So we're in a state of hostilities, and Bill Barr, by my lights, is performing ably, but he's also performing reasonably.  Why walk into a situation when you know, I mean, here's Nancy Pelosi, right, Neil, already saying you lied.  That's a polite way of saying it.

And the worst thing that happened to Bill Barr and maybe the administration is this.  enormously, stunningly good employment report, because if you're a Democrat, you've got to find something else to talk about, and this is fodder.
Politically, let's let the Attorney General, who's capable of taking all kinds of heat, take the heat.  Mr.  President, talk about the economy.  Let Bill Barr handle this investigation on all fronts.

But do you worry, even though you rightly are, Republicans have argued, let's have an investigation as to have this investigation started, that Americans polled on this subject, and you can go any poll, they say, enough.

enough doesn't matter.  this doesn't matter because we need to know the truth.  we have been through these two years of uncertainty someone's.  we've been 22 months of hell.  we've got to find out.  how did all this begin?  you know you shall know the truth.
all right ken.  thank you very much.

James Comey talking about his firing from the FBI tonight says he sees potential obstruction of justice by the president, but also says all Americans should be gratified by the no collusion conclusion.  Let's bring in Fox News senior political analyst Brit Hume for reaction.  What do you think about all the fallout the last couple of days as people are now putting their own spin on the Barr letter and the Mueller report?

Well, people don't seem to know whether to try to spin the bar letter or to denounce the bar letter.  My own sense about that, Shannon, is this.  I think we'll probably trust the bar letter as being an accurate representation, and broadly speaking, of what is in the Mueller report.  For this reason, first of all, Barr as a guy didn't need this job.  He's got, you know, had a long career.  He's been Attorney General before.  He has a good reputation.  I don't think he's going to put that reputation at risk for some spin, to spin a report whose contents are going to become known anyway.  I mean, that would be an act of insanity.  So I don't think that people who are pinning their hopes on that ought to keep those hopes up very high.
The former FBI Director Comey also had this to say about what the Mueller report does to shed some light on the FBI.

It establishes, I hope, to all people, no matter where they are on the spectrum, that the FBI is not corrupt, not a nest of vipers and spies, but an honest group of people trying to find out what is true.
Is that the way you see the report?

I don't know how much the report is going to have to say about the performance of the FBI.  It seems to me that's in the hands of others right now.  But that wouldn't necessarily be the conclusion I would draw from the outcome of this investigation.  I think that, by and large, that is true about the FBI.  But James Comey and those who work closely with him do not fit that description, in my opinion.  I mean, that's, you know, a bunch of people got fired and with good reason.  And Comey was one of them.  So, you know, I suspect he may hope that because he thinks.  if people start thinking that, they may think better of him.

Well, we're still waiting on the Inspector General's report about what was going on with some of these FISA applications and other things.  So we're waiting on that.  But in the meantime, across town at the CIA, John Brennan was the CIA director for years.  And Rand Paul said today this.  He says, breaking a high-level source tells me it was Brennan who insisted that the unverified and fake Steele dossier be included in the intelligence report.  Brennan should be asked to testify under oath in Congress immediately.  And a lot of folks say if that's the case, he immediately gave credibility to the dossier as the CIA director by including it in that intel assessment.

Well, I don't doubt that.  But Brennan's problem now is, it seems to me, is that he has been.  he has exposed himself as such an ardent Trump hater.  And, you know, his projections about this, his read on how the Mueller investigation was going to turn out, has turned out to be, both those things have turned out to be all wrong.  And, you know, he's had now at least to acknowledge that he, you know, he thought there'd be more than there turned out to be.  Well, no kidding.  And, you know, this man, this man Brennan, behaved like no other former intelligence chief I've ever seen behave.  I mean, I cannot imagine, for example, William Webster, who headed both the FBI and CIA at one point, ever making the kind of partisan accusations he's made against his president.  He called him a traitor.  Yeah, treasonous behavior.  Yeah, I mean, treasonous behavior.  That is an extreme assertion that no responsible former intelligence chief should make unless he is prepared to present hard evidence that it's true, which he manifestly has not.

OK, so obviously the issues with collusion were not proven.  The special counsel says no one connected to the Trump campaign.  We didn't see it, according to the bar letter.  And as you said, he'd have no reason to mischaracterize it because he knows the rest of this is going to come out.  But for a lot of Democrats, that's just.  that's off the checklist now.  And it's on to impeachment.  And some of them today are continuing.  The leadership doesn't want them to talk about it.  They're continuing to talk about it.  Congressman Al Green, Democrat from Texas, he's already.  they've already voted a couple of times on his impeachment plans.  Here's what he says.

A president does not have to commit a crime to be impeached.  We have, unfortunately, allowed some persons to conflate what the special counsel was doing, what Mr.  Mueller was doing, with what the House can do.
Yeah, a much lower level than making a legal case on the issues.

In the end, impeachment is a political question.  But it's also the case, Mr.  Green notwithstanding, that the Constitution speaks of high crimes and misdemeanors.  So that's the reason why people sort of get the idea that you have to commit a crime in order to be impeached as president.  It's not true.  A high crime for Congress is for impeachment purposes, whatever Congress says it is.  But that's kind of where we are.  Let me make one other point, though.  Not everybody's given up on collusion.  That's true.  Adam Schiff is still banging on about it and is tonight.  And, you know, people keep asserting, well, what Mueller found was that what Trump did didn't rise to the level of a crime or that he couldn't make the case.  That's not exactly what the summary said.  The summary said he didn't find any collusion.  He didn't say any criminal collusion or anything else.  It said no collusion.  And there's a quote from the Mueller report, did not find cooperation, collaboration between Trump.
Despite repeated attempts.
Despite.  Yes.  And it went on to say that the Russians had tried to seduce the Trump campaign and failed.  So that's pretty definitive.
That doesn't mean the search for other possible trouble for the president will end here.  So that's the next chapter that we go into.  Meantime, Brett, always great to have you.
Thanks, Shannon.  Glad to be here.  The quote from the Mueller report did not find cooperation, collaboration between Trump.
Despite repeated attempts.
Despite, yes.
From people on the Russian side.
The Russians had tried to seduce the Trump campaign and failed.  So that's pretty definitive.
That doesn't mean the search for other possible trouble for the president will end here.  So that's the next chapter that we go into.  Meantime, Britt, always great to have you.
Thanks, Shannon.  Glad to be here.
